text:
JEAN CASAREZ:
Here's the one thing

you need to know about President
Trump's executive order
on deportation priorities.

The order broadens categories
of the undocumented immigrant

previously targeted by
the Obama administration
but offers fewer specifics.
[music playing]

Topping the list for President
Trump's executive order

on deportation priorities
are those people

who have been convicted
of any criminal offense,

those who have been charged
of any criminal offense,

and then people who
could be charged
with a criminal offense.

Further down on the list,
but still a priority,

are those people who are subject
to a final order of removal.

In other words, they have been
notified that they will be

deported from the United States,
but it's just a matter of when.

In 2014, then Homeland
Security Secretary Jeh Johnson

issued the Obama
administration's guidance,

a priority enforcement program
that focused in on three areas
for apprehension and removal.

Number one priority
for deportation,

national security
threats, convicted

felons or aggravated felons,
criminal gang participants,
illegal entries at the border.

Number two priority for
deportation, individuals

convicted of significant
or multiple misdemeanors,

individuals who unlawfully
have entered or re-entered

the country after January
2014, or people who have
abused the visa waiver program.

Number three priority
for deportation,

individuals who
have failed to abide
by a final order of removal.

Under Obama's
administration, there

were more deportations
in his two terms
than under any other president.

And as far as how many removals
there will be during the Trump
years, no one knows for sure.
[music playing]
